oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mayor John Boyd Thacher, II, with Chinese-American Children
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three Chinese-American girls and one Chinese-American boy are handing money to Mayor John Boyd Thacher, II, in an event staged to show homefront efforts towards raising money for World War II efforts.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a printed Bill of Fare for the Albany, N.Y. Alms House. The bill was printed by the order of the Common Council with CHAs. D. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Municipal Airport
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mayor John Boyd Thatcher II purchased land for the site of the current airport in 1928 from the Watervliet Shakers, creating the first municipal airport. The Albany airport has changed and expanded many times since then, most recently in 1993 in a $184 million renovation project that resulted in a new name, Albany International Airport.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The largest private employer of black labor in the United States by the 1920s, the Pullman Company provided African Americans with stable jobs as waiters and porters on train lines including the New York Central.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Albany Yacht Club and Maiden Lane Railroad Bridge looking east
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the Albany Yacht Club and the Maiden Lane Bridge. The Yatch Club was established in 1873. It has moved numerous times as the waterfront of Albany has changed. The Maiden Lane Bridge was a railroad bridge across the Hudson River between the city of Albany and Rensselaer County, New York. The bridge was removed when the Albany-Rensselaer Amtrak Station was opened across the river in Rensselaer in 1968. The bridge was referred to as South Bridge.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Trophy Point
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Stereo view of the circle of 13 original iron chains at Trophy Point, West Point Military Academy. In 1778 George Washington ordered Polish engineer Colonel Thaddeus Kosciusko to construct an iron chain to block passage of British ships from sailing to Albany. The chain streched between West Point and Constitution Island. A ring of thirteen original links, respenting thee thirteen American colonies, attracts tourists to the grounds of West Point Military Academy.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New York (State)--History--Revolution, 1775-1783; American Revolution;
Photographs; Stereographs

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Robert R. Henry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement for groceries at Robert R. Henry's store on 1 Quay Street. Robert R. Henry (1771-1851) was an area merchant and one of the initial trustees of the Albany Public Library. His store, located along the docks at the Albany basin, offered a complete assortment of groceries inlcuding produce,coffee, teas, wines, brandy, spices oils and a variety of products from the West Indies. In exchange for these goods, Albany exported fur, meat, wheat and lumber.He owned a house on Market Street. He moved his business to the American South around 1815.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Henry, Robert R. (1771 - 1851)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Grocers; Advertising;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: God Save Union
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It was common practice in the 19th century to call a "convention" to hear the reading of a momentous statement. In this case The Emancipation Proclamation. On January 5th, 1863, Frederick Douglas spoke at the Baptist Church on Hamilton Street on the subject of emancipation. The event was sponsered by the Friends of Freedom of Albany County.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stephen Meyers et.al.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Slavery; Abolitionists; Antislavery movements; African American abolitionists;

oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Fair use copy permitted for research, study, or investigational purposes citing the Albany Institute of History & Art. Any other use requires written permission.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Splendid Red Coaches, Albany and Whitehall Express
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The stagecoach connected with Lake Champlain steamboats, enabling travelers to reach Montreal. The Albany to Whitehall coach ride was a twelve hour journey. Travelers left from Young & Walbridge's Stage Office on 500 South Market in Albany traveled onto Troy then onto Whitehall at the Phoenix Hotel and Clinton House.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Harness Race
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An advertisement for three days of harness racing taking place in Albany from September 30 through October 2nd, 1868. The total purse was $6000 for the six races. Results of the first day of the races can be found in the October 2, 1868 edition of the New York Times. The race took place on Park Island which no longer exists since the buidling of I-787.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Albany Nursery
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Albany Nursery was established by Jesse Beul (1778-1839) in 1821. Mr. Beul was active in the agricultural improvements. On his 85-acre farm established just west of Albany in the area known as the Sandy Barrens, he put to practice the principles of crop rotation and green manures. In 1834, he founded the newspaper The Cultivator to keep farmers informed of new agricultural methods.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Cultivator
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An advertisement for three publications from Luther Tucker and Son of Albany. The first one is The Cultivator. A monthly journal devoted to agriculture, horticulture and floriculture. The second is a weekly paper called The Country Gentleman. The last is The Illustrated Annual Register of Rural Affairs and Cultivator Almanac. Luther Tucker was a member of the New York State Agriculutral Society and an ardent support of the New York State Fair.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
